Award.AwardTitle: Wind Turbine Array Performance Based on Coupling CFD with Doppler Lidar Measurements

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Peet, Yulia
Proposal Number: 1335868
Institution: Arizona State University
Title: Wind Turbine Array Performance Based on Coupling CFD with Doppler Lidar Measurements

As the size of the modern wind turbines grow, the effect of the atmospheric boundary layer (ABL) variability on their operation becomes significantly more important. This project will develop and validate a novel methodology to integrate field wind velocity measurements obtained by the Doppler lidar into a high-fidelity computational model for wind plant flow and power characterization. Doppler lidar measurements give the most reliable information of the microscale meteorological structures modulated by the regional terrain and local weather patterns. High-fidelity wind plant flow models based on Large Eddy Simulations (LES) generate highly-resolved spatio-temporal data including unsteady turbine loads for assessing the structural response and power performance. When driven by realistic atmospheric measurements, LES simulations will provide invaluable information to study the unsteady response of wind turbine arrays to the stochastic atmospheric environment. Knowledge of these unsteady responses is required to create reliable models for wind turbine control and wind farm layout optimization.

A unique multiscale approach will be develop to propagate the effects of the sub-mesoscale atmospheric motion captured by the real-time observations down to the wind plant and wind turbine scales governed by the viscous effects and blade/wake interactions. This approach will combine the optimal interpolation assimilation of the Doppler lidar data to retrieve the vector field information, reconstructing the smaller scales by driving the auxiliary ABL LES simulations to match the lidar observations, and integrating the assimilated spatio-temporal stochastic inflow with the state-of-the-art wind plant flow characterization model based on LES and actuator line aerodynamics.

Using a novel computational experiments the PIs will be able to study the effects of spatio-temporal wind variability on unsteady turbine loads and wake physics, and computationally isolate the different sources of variability such as wind turbulence, wind speed shear, wind directional shear, with the goal of characterizing the relative strengths of these effects and creating the most reliable simplified inflow models that capture the essential physics. The creation of simplified models is crucial for improving design parameters and standards for wind turbine industry. The numerical simulations are based on high-order spectral element computational solver Nek5000 developed and supported by Argonne National Laboratory that currently offers the most efficient utilization of high-end computing resources due to its high-order accuracy and extreme scalability.

Understanding spatio-temporal responses of wind plants to realistic wind conditions will result in improved design and reduction of uncertainty, thus lowering Levelized Cost of Energy (LCOE). The lessons learned and the topics discovered will be broadly disseminated within the scientific community. This project will be a central theme for providing hands-on research and educational experience for the local high-school students. Through competitive diversity-oriented scholarships, PIs will work with four high-school students including minority, female and low-income students, over the summer following the second year of the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectural Merit: In this project, a methodology was developed that assimilates wind field data collected by a Doppler lidar upstream of a wind farm, into a numerical Large Eddy Simulation (LES) that models an unsteady dynamics of the fluid flow and its interaction with wind turbines. The developed simulation model resolves fluctuating turbulent motions down to a spatial scale of less than one meter, and a temporal scale of less than 0.1s. The effect of the rotating turbine blades on the flow is modeled with the Actuator Line model that approximates this effect by inclusion of body force terms into the equations. The novelty of the research is in integration of realistic wind data into LES simulations of wind farms. Intellectual merit of the project consists of finding a robust way of incorporating coarser lidar measurements (with a spatial scale of approximately 30m and a temporal scale of approximately 1min) into a finer resolution of numerical simulations, such that the missing scales of motions are properly reconstructed. The significance of the current development is that many interesting physical effects associated with the interaction of a realistic atmospheric turbulence and the rotating wind turbine blades, can now be investigated, and their influence on wind warm performance can be analyzed. In particular, the current development allowed us to obtain several new scientific results related to the influence of wake dynamics on the wind farm operations, as detailed in the Outcomes section of the current report. 

Broader Impacts: The developed methodologies provide a framework for achieving an improved understanding of the influence of realistic wind conditions on the wind farm performance and set a stage for new technological innovations that will lead to more efficient wind farms and a reduced cost of energy. The impact of these technologies on the society at large is in providing a cheaper and cleaner energy which will enhance the modern energy infrastructure and reduce the environmental burden. The current project provided a significant opportunity for workforce development and education: two Ph.D. students were involved in a scientific research and academic publishing as full-time research assistants, an engangement of undergraduate students in research was achieved through FURI program at ASU, and graduate students benefited from enhanced curriculum of the graduate classes "Advanced CFD", "Advanced Turbulence", and "Wind Energy" taught by PI and Co-PI that incorporated the current research findings. The developed numerical models and enhancements to the open source code have been merged with a publicly releasable version of the code, and were made available to the public through the open-access repository on GitHub. 

Project Outcomes: The following is the list of the project outcomes and significant results obtained as the result of the current research.

1) A new parameterization of the algebraic subgrid scale turbulence model was developed for a numerical simulation of atmospheric boundary layers interacting with wind turbine arrays [1-4] (Figures 1, 2).

2) Length scales of turbulent eddies responsible for the power production in large wind farms were analyzed (Figure 3). It was established that the structures of the size 10 and more turbine diameters make the largest contribution to power [5-7]. 

3) A potential of vertically-staggered "multiscale wind farms" to provide more efficient wind energy capture was discovered (Figure 4). This symbioitc effect was analyzed and explained from the fluid mechanics perspective [8].

4) A new wind retrieval algorithm for the lidar data processing was proposed [9] and applied to the data acquisition in the Tehachapi Pass wind farm [10], and to the aicraft vortex data [11]. 

5) A capability of numerical simulations to incorporate realistic wind effects and capture large-scale structures observed in a field data downstream of a wind farm was evaluated by comparing the results of the lidar data driven simulations with the field data [12] (Figures 5, 6).
